ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course teaches you not just about some fascinating early societies, but also makes student's question their use of language when creating scientific studies and viewing human nature through the lens of archaeological science.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course has some very good readings, and the speakers who covered various sites they specialized in were detailed and helpful in understanding - to the best of our ability - the functioning of ancient societies. I enjoyed the class discussions. While I find them somewhat intimidating - I always fear I'll mess up what I'm trying to say - the philosophical discussions that occur between students and professors in this course are fascinating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students who are interested in viewing ancient societies through a theoretical and philosophical lens. I would highly recommend it to students interested in archaeological studies, but would also suggest it for those of a more historical mindset.
Absolutely. This course was critical to my understanding of archaeology having limited experience in the field.
